title: AB 1850
content: The State of California enacts the following. Section 13000 of the Education Code is amended to establish the California Civil Liberties Public Education Act, aimed at educating the public about the internment of Japanese Americans during World War II. The federal Commission on Wartime Relocation and Internment of Civilians (CWRIC) was created by Congress in 1980 to review Executive Order 9066's impact on American citizens and recommend remedies. The CWRIC issued reports in 1983 based on hearings with over 750 witnesses, including evacuees, government officials, and historians. The federal Commission on Wartime Relocation and Internment of Civilians (CWRIC) concluded that Executive Order 9066, which led to the internment of Japanese-Americans during World War II, was not justified by military necessity. The decisions made were driven by race prejudice, war hysteria, and a failure of political leadership. President Ronald Reagan signed the federal Civil Liberties Act of 1988, acknowledging the grave personal injustice done to American citizens and resident aliens of Japanese ancestry. The Congress acknowledges the grave injustice done to individuals of Japanese ancestry during World War II, apologizing for the violation of their civil liberties and constitutional rights. The Education Code is also amended in response to this acknowledgment. The Education Code is amended to establish a state test for eligible aliens seeking permanent residency in California under the federal Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986. This test would assess their understanding of English, history, and government of the United States to meet federal requirements. The Education Code is amended to establish a state test for eligible undocumented foreign nationals seeking permanent residency in California under the federal Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986. This test would assess their understanding of English, history, and government of the United States to meet federal requirements. The Education Code is amended to establish a state test for eligible undocumented foreign nationals seeking permanent residency in California under the federal Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986. The Superintendent, in consultation with the Chancellor of the California Community Colleges, will develop or adopt a test to measure English proficiency and knowledge of U.S. history and government as required by federal law. The Governor and other officials will petition for approval to use this test for foreign nationals to meet federal requirements. The Superintendent will distribute a test to educational agencies for eligible foreign nationals applying for legal status, to assess English proficiency and knowledge of U.S. history and government. Test results are confidential and can only be released with written consent for educational purposes. Test results for eligible foreign nationals applying for legal status in the United States are confidential and can only be released with written consent for educational purposes. Upon request, test results may be transmitted to the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service. Educational agencies receiving federal funds must administer the test with appropriate security measures in place. Section 52613 of the Education Code is amended to require school districts enrolling nonimmigrant foreign nationals in adult classes to charge a fee covering the full cost of instruction, not exceeding the actual cost. The fee must be adopted at least 90 days before the classes begin. Section 52651 of the Education Code defines key terms for the California Community Colleges, including the Board of Governors, Chancellor, community-based organizations, Department of Education, and educational outreach activities. Community-based organizations are approved by the Superintendent to provide educational services to eligible legalized persons. The Department refers to the State Department of Education. Educational outreach activities involve providing information to temporary resident foreign nationals about the Immigration and Nationality Act of 1986, including adjustment of resident status, sources of assistance, rights and responsibilities, and identifying health, employment, and social services. The curr_chunk discusses educational opportunities for immigrants, defining terms like "immigrant" and "newly legalized person." It also defines a "services provider" as an approved organization to provide educational services to newly legalized persons. The curr_chunk defines key terms related to educational services for immigrants, including "services provider," "SLIAG," and "Superintendent." It also outlines rules for determining a person's residence. The curr_chunk outlines rules for determining a person's residence, including the definition of a residence, how it can be established or changed, and specific rules for minors' residences. The curr_chunk discusses rules for establishing residence, including restrictions for minors and foreign nationals. It also amends Section 68130.5 of the Education Code regarding nonresident tuition exemptions for certain students in California. The curr_chunk outlines the requirements for exemption from nonresident tuition in California, including high school attendance, graduation from a California high school, enrollment in an accredited institution of higher education, and filing an affidavit for individuals without lawful immigration status. The curr_chunk discusses the implementation and confidentiality of student information for those exempt from nonresident tuition in California. Additionally, it mentions the amendment to Section 69505 of the Education Code regarding the exclusion of reparation payments from financial need calculations. The curr_chunk discusses the conditions for Sections 3 to 8 of the act to become operative, requiring certification related to federal government terminology changes. It also exempts reparation payments from financial need calculations. The curr_chunk addresses the replacement of terms like "alien" with "foreign national" and "illegal alien" with "undocumented foreign national" in reference to individuals in the United States. If the Superintendent of Public Instruction certifies it, Section 2 of the act will become inoperative.
